global_flags.description: When Cumulative time mode is On, each process is listed with the cpu time that it and its dead children have used.  See the `S' interactive command for additional information regarding this mode.

top  in  Batch mode, which could be useful for sending output from top to other programs or to a file.  In this mode, top will not accept input and runs until the iterations limit you've set with the `-n' command-line option or until killed.
Thus, if top was displaying command lines,  now  that  field  will  show  program names, and vice versa.  See the `c' interactive command for additional information.

the  delay  between  screen  updates, and overrides the corresponding value in one's personal configuration file or the startup default.  Later this can be changed with the `d' or `s' interactive commands.
only  processes  with  a  user  id or user name matching that given.  This option matches on any user (real, effective, saved, or filesystem).
This option matches on the effective user id only.
When this toggle is Off, tasks that have not used any CPU since the  last  update will not be displayed.  For additional information regarding this toggle see topic 4c. TASK AREA Commands, SIZE.

option  acts  as  a  form  of help for the -o option shown below.  It will cause top to print each of the available field names on a separate line, then quit.  Such names are subject to NLS (National Language Support) translation.
However, when combined with Threads mode (`H'), all processes in the thread group (see TGID) of each monitored PID will also be shown.
This mode is far better controlled through a system configuration file (see  topic  6. FILES).
Either all cpu information will be  displayed  in  a single line or each cpu will be displayed separately, depending on the state of the NUMA Node command toggle (`2').

reflected  in  the  configuration  file.   You  can prepend  a  `+' or `-' to the field name to also override the sort direction.  A leading `+' will force sorting high to low, whereas a `-' will ensure a low to high ordering.
Without this command-line option a summation of all threads in each process is shown.  Later this can be changed with the `H' interactive command.

output  using  the  COLUMNS=  and  LINES=  environment  variables,  if  set. Otherwise,  width  will be fixed at the maximum 512 columns.  With an argument, output width can be decreased or increased (up to 512) but the number of rows is considered unlimited.

subcommands.name: nMaj
subcommands.description: -- Major Page Fault Count

subcommands.name: nMin
subcommands.description: -- Minor Page Fault count

subcommands.name: nTH
subcommands.description: -- Number of Threads The number of threads associated with a process.

subcommands.name: nsCGROUP
subcommands.description: -- CGROUP namespace The Inode of the namespace used to hide the identity of the control group of which process is a member.

subcommands.name: nsIPC
subcommands.description: -- IPC namespace

subcommands.name: nsMNT
subcommands.description: -- MNT namespace The Inode of the namespace used to isolate filesystem mount points thus offering different views of the filesystem hierarchy.

subcommands.name: nsNET
subcommands.description: -- NET namespace The Inode of the namespace used to isolate resources such as network devices, IP addresses, IP routing, port numbers, etc.

subcommands.name: nsPID
subcommands.description: -- PID namespace

subcommands.name: nsTIME
subcommands.description: -- TIME namespace The Inode of the namespace which allows processes to see different system times in a way similar to the UTS namespace.

subcommands.name: nsUSER
subcommands.description: -- USER namespace

subcommands.name: nsUTS
subcommands.description: -- UTS namespace

subcommands.description: pebibytes

subcommands.name: t
subcommands.description: tebibytes

subcommands.name: total
subcommands.description: ( MemTotal )

subcommands.name: unsatisfactory
subcommands.description: display as the system and tty driver try to keep up with top's demands. The delay value is inversely proportional to system loading, so set it with care.

subcommands.name: v
subcommands.description: :Hide/Show-Children toggle When in forest view mode, this key serves as a toggle to collapse or expand the children of a parent.

subcommands.name: vMj
subcommands.description: -- Major Page Fault Count Delta The number of major page faults that have occurred since the last update (see nMaj).

subcommands.name: vMn
subcommands.description: -- Minor Page Fault Count Delta The number of minor page faults that have occurred since the last update (see nMin).

subcommands.name: variables
subcommands.description: if set. With an argument, output width can only be decreased, not increased. Whether using environment variables or an argument with -w, when not in Batch mode actual terminal dimensions can never be exceeded.

subcommands.name: vertical
subcommands.description: scrolled position, however, will not be affected. See topic 5c. SCROLLING a Window for additional information regarding vertical and horizontal scrolling.

subcommands.name: virtual
subcommands.description: page that is not currently present in its address space. A major page fault is when auxiliary storage access is involved in making that page available.
